articles.headline: Cellphone Payments Offer Alternative to Cash
articles.snippet: As companies develop ways to pay for goods and services using cellphones, the wallet is looking old-fashioned.
articles.abstract: As companies develop ways to pay for goods and services using cellphones, the wallet is looking old-fashioned.
articles.lead_paragraph: You win a bet, but the loser does not have enough cash on him to settle it. If he has a credit card, and most people usually do, there is finally a solution. A number of big and small companies — including eBay’s PayPal unit, Intuit, VeriFone and Square — are creating innovative ways for individuals to avoid cash and checks and settle all debts, public and private, using their cellphones.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Republicans Allow Debate on Financial Overhaul
articles.snippet: After days of resistance, Senate Republicans agreed to let Democrats open debate on a bill to regulate the financial system.
articles.abstract: After days of resistance, Senate Republicans agreed to let Democrats open debate on a bill to regulate the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With political pressure mounting, Senate Republicans relented on Wednesday and agreed to let Democrats open debate on legislation that would impose the most far-reaching overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system since the aftermath of the Depression.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Edward Wyatt

articles.headline: Your Phone Is Locked. Just Drive.
articles.snippet: New cellphone apps take aim at drivers — young ones, especially — who text or make calls while behind the wheel.
articles.abstract: New cellphone apps take aim at drivers — young ones, especially — who text or make calls while behind the wheel.
articles.lead_paragraph: The statistics on distracted driving are pretty scary. Just making cellphone calls increases your chances of crashing by four times; sending text messages increases the risk 23 times.

articles.headline: H.P. to Pay $1.2 Billion for Palm
articles.snippet: The deal will combine two companies that have had difficulty competing in the smartphone market.
articles.abstract: The deal will combine two companies that have had difficulty competing in the smartphone market.
articles.lead_paragraph: With its $1.2 billion purchase of Palm, Hewlett-Packard signaled that it would take drastic action to remain relevant to consumers whose tastes in computing devices were radically changing.
articles.byline: By Ashlee Vance and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Goldman and Its Lobbyists Spurned in Fight on Bill
articles.snippet: Lawmakers are keeping their distance from Goldman Sachs and its well-connected lobbyists.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers are keeping their distance from Goldman Sachs and its well-connected lobbyists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last week, White House officials quietly approached leading financial firms seeking formal letters of support for a Congressional overhaul of financial regulations. One Wall Street powerhouse was left off the list: Goldman Sachs.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Eric Dash

articles.headline:
In British Race, a Stray Remark
Haunts Brown
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Gordon Brown’s insult of a potential Labour voter, caught live on microphone, could cost his party votes.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Gordon Brown’s insult of a potential Labour voter, caught live on microphone, could cost his party votes.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Maybe it was proof of the maxim that a gaffe is when a politician tells the truth. Or maybe it was evidence that Prime Minister Gordon Brown, for all he tries to be nice, might actually be kind of mean.

articles.headline: Already Holding Junk, Germany Hesitates
articles.snippet: Germany’s exposure to Greek debt, estimated to be $37 billion by Barclays Capital, already exceeds the $11 billion the country would lend to Greece as part of an initial European Union bailout plan.
articles.abstract: Germany’s exposure to Greek debt, estimated to be $37 billion by Barclays Capital, already exceeds the $11 billion the country would lend to Greece as part of an initial European Union bailout plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Add this to the list of reasons German taxpayers are unhappy about having to lend Greece money to ease its debt crisis: In effect, they already have.
